issue.title: Broken Sidekiq <> Datadog Integration with version 5.6.1
issue.body:
Hello,

We encountered an issue with the official Datadog Sidekiq integration on our [Va.gov API](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/vets-api) after upgrading to version 5.6.1. Metrics (only for Sidekiq) stopped coming into Datadog. After downgrading back to 5.6.0, the metrics resumed as expected. For context, our Sidekiq pods operate within EKS. I'm highlighting this in case it's relevant to others facing similar challenges. For reference, you can view our dogstatsd-ruby configuration [here](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/vets-api/blob/master/config/initializers/datadog.rb). Additionally, we followed the direct Datadog instructions for setting up the Datadog <> Sidekiq Integration.

Best regards,
Lindsey Hattamer
Tech Lead, Va.gov Platform

comment.body:
Hi @LindseySaari, I suspect the issue might require us to take a peek into Sidekiq-Pro's code, and how `dogstastd` is being used there.

Because Sidekiq-Pro's source code is not publicly distributable, could you please submit an issue so we can look into this problem with our support team and can exchange non-public information through that channel: https://help.datadoghq.com/hc/en-us/requests/new

issue.title: TCP support for non datadog usage
issue.body:
This statsd client is pretty good and I understand its supposed to be used with datadog as a part of its ecosystem. But this client is also can be used with other backends(like statsd or telegraf with statsd plugin). And sometimes its not possible to use udp because of some reasons. Are you interested in supporting tcp format for such cases?

I have a fork with tcp support, so if you are interested I can prepare a PR

comment.body:
Hey @Koilanetroc 

Thank you for reaching us about this! Supporting TCP is not part of `dogstatsd-ruby` roadmap for now. It does not mean you can't send a pull-request with your proposal, others people might see it and benefit from it. However, I don't plan on merging such a change as it implies future maintenance for something that's not planned for now. I hope you understand.

issue.title: TCP support for non datadog usage
issue.body:
This statsd client is pretty good and I understand its supposed to be used with datadog as a part of its ecosystem. But this client is also can be used with other backends(like statsd or telegraf with statsd plugin). And sometimes its not possible to use udp because of some reasons. Are you interested in supporting tcp format for such cases?

I have a fork with tcp support, so if you are interested I can prepare a PR

issue.title: Support IP changes of statsd hostname
issue.body:
we have the issue that the ip address of our statsd host is changing regularly on our kubernetes cluster due to some automated updates. In this case the current implementation continues to send UDP packets to the old IP address.

This pr addresses this issue by resolving the hostname to its ip all 60 seconds. in case the ip changed, it simply reconnects the UDP socket.

This is a bit of a draft to get your input. Please let me know if this is something you would be willing to merge

FYI this currently failes the allocation specs as I did not adapt those yet

comment.body:
@remeh Thanks for your comment. While your proposed mitigation works I would expect from such a library that it can reconnect itself automatically in such a case, as library user I don't want to take care of this myself.

As for the problems:
For when the dns resolution fails, it could be ignored and the socket left intact. Then retry the resolution only again at the next interval. So it would not change in terms of behavior compared to what it is doing now.

As for speed considerations when the dns resolution is slow. Maybe add a low timeout, e.g.
```
Resolv::DNS.open do |dns|
  dns.timeouts = 0.1
  ip = dns.getname(hostname)
end
```
This would mean the thread is blocked at max 100ms every minute (not sure if that is enough though). Also this behavior could be made configurable with custom timeouts or even disable it completely
Or as  suggested above, we could make it async with a Fiber or so

issue.title: Support IP changes of statsd hostname
issue.body:
we have the issue that the ip address of our statsd host is changing regularly on our kubernetes cluster due to some automated updates. In this case the current implementation continues to send UDP packets to the old IP address.

This pr addresses this issue by resolving the hostname to its ip all 60 seconds. in case the ip changed, it simply reconnects the UDP socket.

This is a bit of a draft to get your input. Please let me know if this is something you would be willing to merge

FYI this currently failes the allocation specs as I did not adapt those yet

comment.body:
my 2 cents, IMHO this should be handled (if enabled) in the statsd library. statsd is often used indirectly by other libraries to report metrics and for example not directly in our applications.
But I can see your concern about slow dns resolution. Wondering if the DNS resolve could maybe be moved into a fiber(more lightweight than a thread and should be ideal here as we're waiting for IO) so it won't block the `send_message` operation.

issue.title: Support IP changes of statsd hostname
issue.body:
we have the issue that the ip address of our statsd host is changing regularly on our kubernetes cluster due to some automated updates. In this case the current implementation continues to send UDP packets to the old IP address.

This pr addresses this issue by resolving the hostname to its ip all 60 seconds. in case the ip changed, it simply reconnects the UDP socket.

This is a bit of a draft to get your input. Please let me know if this is something you would be willing to merge

FYI this currently failes the allocation specs as I did not adapt those yet

comment.body:
Hey @Goltergaul

Thanks for you contribution.

A problem with this implementation is that the `Resolv.getaddress` call can be slow (even if returning the same IP). It will block the thread during the DNS resolve, and thus the application calling the library. Even if fast, the DNS resolve could start to fail for some reasons and nothing would indicate an error with the current implementation + the IP would not be known anymore by the client instance (while still being possibly reachable).

A mitigation to your problem which can be considered with the `dogstatsd-ruby` client and which would mimick your implementation would be that every 60s, your application calls the `flush` method and then re-creates the client instance. WDYT?

issue.title: Documentation around 4 -> 5 upgrade; ArgumentError: Start sender first
issue.body:
I'm unsure what I need to do to make the 4 to 5 upgrade work. I see the README file has some detail:

- Using a singleton instance of the DogStatsD client instead of creating a new instance whenever you need one; this will let the buffering mechanism flush metrics regularly
- Or properly disposing of the DogStatsD client instance when it is not needed anymore using the method Datadog::Statsd#close

but I thought we were using a singleton instance, and I don't think we want to be sprinkling `#close` around the code. The current way we're creating the instance is in an initialiser:

```ruby
require 'datadog/statsd'

Rails.configuration.statsd = Datadog::Statsd.new(
  tags: {
    env: Rails.env
  },
  disable_telemetry: Rails.env != 'production'
)
```

then we use it like so:

```ruby
Rails.configuration.statsd.distribution('elasticsearch.client.response_time', duration, tags: tags)
```

Deployed on Heroku using Puma, we're getting an error `#<ArgumentError: Start sender first>` that is crashing the Rails (6.1.7.3) process on boot. Is there something else we should be doing?

comment.body: Hey Scott, if you've got it a canonical example of what a datadog config looks like when using Puma in pre-forking mode would be really helpful here.

release.name: v5.6.1
release.body:
## 5.6.1 / 2023.09.07

 * [IMPROVEMENT] Add support for IPv6 UDP connection. https://github.com/DataDog/dogstatsd-ruby/issues/280 by [@kazwolfe](https://github.com/kazwolfe)

5.6.1 / 2023.09.07

  • [IMPROVEMENT] Add support for IPv6 UDP connection. #280 by @kazwolfe
